!+1+ Textual Note: AIO includes readings and supplements in col. 3, ll. 15–16 ([Ν]ικαρ[χος ... | ...]νίου), col. 4, l. 4 (Σ[τρ]ἀ[τω]ν Ῥί[νων]ος) from F.Delphes III 2, add. p. 287; in col. 3, l. 8 ([Μαρ]σύας) from Tracy, BCH 99, 1975, 191.
This is a list of 47 names of Pythaist-boys who participated in the second Pythais at Delphi, which took place in 128/7 BC. It was inscribed on two horizontally joined blocks in the southern façade of the Athenian Treasury, below the list of Pythaist-boys of the first Pythais of 138/7 BC (F.Delphes III 2, 11). On the Pythais and the Treasury, see F.Delphes III 2, 3 and on Attic inscriptions at Delphi, see IG II3 4, 17 with notes. The first three lines, which serve as a preamble, were inscribed across both blocks, aligned to the left with large letterspaces. G. Daux, Delphes au IIe et au Ier siècle, 1936, 524 (followed by Tracy, ALC, 257) notes that the script of this inscription is distinct from other texts in the second Pythais: for instance, the alpha was written here with four rather than three strokes (cf. also F.Delphes III 2, 8, with notes).!

!+2+ Pythaist-boys participated in the Pythais procession as part of a chorus under the direction of a chorus director (didaskalos chorou, cf. F.Delphes III 2, 11, l. 20 and F.Delphes III 2, 47, l. 8). They may have sung the hymns and paians during the procession (see Pöhlmann and West, Greek Music 20-21). Lists of Pythaist-boys survive from all the four Pythaides: F.Delphes III 2, 11 (138/7 BC), F.Delphes III 2, 15 (106/5 BC), and F.Delphes III 2, 17 (97/6 BC). Participation was a mark of status, as fathers of several boys here also participate in the Pythais as cavalrymen or theoroi. Many of the boys would later become ephebes and Pythaists (on Pythaist-boys, see S. Kühn, Pythais-Prozession, 2018, 150-151; for the role of family bonds, see K. Karila-Cohen in M. Dana and I. Savalli-Lestrade eds.,La cité interconnectée dans le monde gréco-romain, 2019, 287-306). It is not clear how the names were grouped or ordered as boys from different demes are listed together, and those from the same deme are often separated (e.g., Attinas in col. 2, l. 8 and Polykleitos in col. 3, l. 4 were both from Phlya). This practice may correspond to its contemporary omission of demes and tribes in Delphic proxeny decrees for Athenians (e.g., F.Delphes III 2, 93).!

!+3+ This Medeios was the eponymous archon in Athens in 101/0 and for three consecutive years from 91/0 to 89/8 BC (IG II2 1713, ll. 9-11), as well as polis priest of Poseidon Erechtheus (Ps. Plut. X. Orat. 843b). His role in funding the fourth Pythais (97/6 BC) is shown in IG II2 2336, in which his name was erased and reinscribed four times (ll. 183-189): see also S. Tracy, IG II2 2336, Contributors of First Fruits for the Pythais, 1982, 66 (= SEG 32.218) and E. Culasso Gastaldi, Cahiers Glotz 14, 2003, 261-2 (also AIO Papers 2, 19-20). [Medeios' totally illegal repeat archonships indicate a seriously disordered constitutional situation in Athens in the lead up to the disastrous decision to oppose Rome in the First Mithridatic War. – Christopher de Lisle]!

!+4+ Dionysios and Niketes are brothers (cf. IG II2 1963 with note on "ephebic twins") and their father Athenobios participated in this Pythais as cavalryman. Niketes would become an ephebe in 117/6 BC (IG II2 1109); both Dionysios and Niketes participated in the third Pythais (106/5 BC) as cavalrymen (F.Delphes III 2, 28: not inscribed side-by-side as here). Dionysios was later supervisor (epimelētes) of the market of Delos in 98/7 BC (I Délos 1711, when Medeios in the previous note was the manager at Delos), and the brothers appear to have been mint magistrates around 97/6 BC (C. Habicht, Chiron 21, 1991, 11). On this family see K. Karila-Cohen in J.-Chr. Couvenhes et al. eds., Mélanges offerts à André Laronde, 2012, 395-409. Other boys who later appear as ephebes include Dorotheos (col. 1, l. 11) and Xenodikos (col. 3, l. 13) in the ephebic catalogue of 122/1 BC (IG II2 1006 + SEG 38.114, col. 4, l. 118 and col. 3, l. 135 respectively); Androkles (col. 2, l. 15), Sosigenes (col. 3, l. 12, with doubt) and Charikles (col. 3, l. 14) later in a list of pre-ephebes (mellepheboi, see IG II3 4, 367, at ll. 13, 19, 14 respectively; on mellepheboi, see IG II3 4, 370 with notes) in around 120 BC; and Leotichos (col. 1, l. 6), Timotheos (col. 1, l. 8), Charimedes (col. 1, l. 9), Hermokles (col. 2, l. 10), Agenor (col. 3, l. 5), Sosigenes (col. 3, l. 12) in the ephebic list in 118/7 BC (IG II2 1008, col. 1, l. 124; col. 3, l. 104; col. 3, l. 125; col. 3, l. 127; col. 1, l. 100; col. 4, l. 108 respectively); Kratermos (col. 1, l. 12) in the ephebic list in 116/5 BC (IG II2 1009, col. 4, l. 67). As these boys took ephebic trainings around ten years later but not in the same year, it can be assumed that they were around ten years old when being Pythaist-boys, and that they did not strictly follow the age criterium (as a result, "ephebic twins" can also simply be non-twin brothers). The frequent overlaps and familial networks among Athenian institutional citizen groups (Pythaist-boys, ephebes, cavalrymen, and magistrates on Delos) in around 150-90 BC characterise a strong 'small world' of elites, who held key military, ritual, economic and civic positions and whose offsprings (male, but also female, e.g. kanēphoroi in F.Delphes III 2, 29–31) participated in civic affairs at a young age through rituals, processions, and ephebic trainings, in preparation for taking key positions of the city-state. On this sociological structure, see now S. Lambert in M. Horster and A. Klöckner eds., Civic Priests, 2012, 67-133; É. Perrin-Saminadayar, Éducation, culture et société à Athènes, 2007, 248-266.
!

!+5+ The brothers Nikophon and Philodromos might have been sons of Philodromos son of Nikophon who was an official visitor (theōros) of the Athenian artists’ association in this Pythais (F.Delphes III 2, 47, l. 7; on the artists, see IG II2 1320 with notes). The patronym 'sons of Philodromos' breaks the layout of the list and was clearly added afterwards. The erroneous patronym '(sons of) Ismenios' was not erased when this correction was made.!

!+6+ The last line was inscribed by a different hand and was later erased (F.Delphes III 2, p. 21). Since the name Polykleitos son of Alexandros already appears in col. 3, l. 4, it seems likely that it was duplicated in error and later erased (but see S. Tracy, BCH 99, 1975, 191).!
